cleaned_text: A Beginner's Guide To Ayurveda & Balancing The 3 Doshas I was researching on the benefits of Ayurveda and i found this cool article online at [mindbodygreen.com](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/0-1117/Ayurveda-Dosha-Types-for-Beginners.html). Do You Know the benefits of Ayurveda ? Read This Article Completely Till The End: Ayurvedic medicine is truly so much more than medicine. This 5,000-year-old practice has its roots in India and has since spread across the world, shaping and improving many lives. The core of ayurveda is focused on prevention. It's based on the concept that general health and wellness rely on a delicate balance between mind, body, and spirit. If you've been searching for a holistic and balanced approach to your overall health, you're in the right place. Ayurvedic medicine focuses on [holistic health](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/0-7401/what-is-holistic-health-why-its-important.html) and wellness, and it's basically the opposite of a "one-size-fits-all" approach. It employs a wide variety of practices—each with its own benefits. Here are just a few of the physical conditions it may be able to help with: 1. It can promote heart health. A [2015 study](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26393992) suggested that ayurvedic medicine can have positive effects on people with coronary heart disease. This isn't all that surprising since the practices of yoga and meditation have been [shown](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3679769/) to help regulate high blood pressure. 2. It can reduce inflammation. By now you've probably heard that [inflammation](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/0-27327/how-to-tell-if-you-have-inflammation-5-things-to-do-to-fix-it-a-doctor-explains.html) plays a role in many diseases. It can be caused by a lack of sleep (or just poor- [quality sleep](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/0-15714/9-signs-youre-not-getting-highquality-sleep.html)), digestive issues, and unhealthy diets. Ayurveda's focus on nutrition, sleep, and mindfulness has the potential to reduce inflammation by addressing its underlying causes. [One study](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5664031/) even shows that ayurvedic herbs like turmeric can help treat inflammatory conditions, such as metabolic syndrome, arthritis, anxiety, and hyperlipidemia. 3. It can improve sleep. Processed snacks, caffeine and alcohol, and ever-present electronics are just some of the modern vices that can disrupt sleep. Ayurveda's more balanced, time-tested approach to healthy eating and [mindfulness](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/0-5979/How-to-Practice-Mindfulness-In-Your-Everyday-Life.html) has the potential to get you a good night's rest. Beyond that, simple practices such as rubbing an ayurvedic oil like [jasmine](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/0-18135/3-sacred-aromas-to-open-your-chakras-cleanse-your-aura.html) or coconut on your temples has a calming effect that could lull you to sleep. 4. It can promote weight loss. While ayurvedic medicine isn't focused on dieting, it can be helpful for maintaining a healthy weight. Specific ayurvedic herbs like [triphala](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5567597/) and [guggul](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10740691) have been associated with weight loss, and exercise and movement like yoga paired with [mindful eating](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/0-16399/6-steps-to-intuitive-mindful-eating.html) can promote a healthier all-around lifestyle. An introduction to the 3 doshas: vata, pitta & kapha. In ayurvedic medicine, in ayurvedic medicine to specify how certain people should eat, sleep, exercise, and what their emotional strengths and weaknesses may be," .The three doshas are represented in everybody but in different amounts. Some people may have a health type (or constitution) that is more dominant in pitta, while another may skew toward vata-kapha dominance. Think of each dosha like a two-way scale, and when the scale is out of balance, it can cause physical and emotional distress. The goal is to get all of your doshas back to the levels at which they naturally exist in your body. Here's a brief introduction to the three doshas and the diet and lifestyle tweaks that can help balance them out. Vata Dosha Vata dosha characteristics. Vata is all about the energy of movement, and it's often associated with the wind. It's an energetic dosha linked with flexibility, creativity, and free-flowing spirit. It's associated with bodily movements like breathing, muscle contraction, and [heart function](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/0-7757/10-essential-nutrients-for-heart-health.html). Someone who is vata dominant might be thin, feel cold often, [have dry skin](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/0-1302/7-Ayurvedic-Skin-Care-Tips-for-Healthy-Glowing-Skin.html), or experience racing thoughts. An imbalance in the vata dosha can result in [anxiety](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/0-23197/what-its-really-like-to-live-with-severe-anxiety-from-someone-whos-been-there.html), fear, and digestive issues like [constipation](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/why-pooping-every-day-is-crucial-for-womens-hormone-balance). Exercises to balance the vata dosha. Anything that brings stability and grounding will be helpful when vata energy takes over. Maybe it's being more rigid about your [morning](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/7-steps-to-creating-a-morning-routine-that-sticks) and [nighttime routines](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/karlie-kloss-morning-nighttime-routine), practicing [a grounding meditation](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/mindfully-connect-with-nature-using-these-summertime-rituals) with your feet in the earth, or setting limits on your [use of technology](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/silicon-valley-parents-are-raising-tech-free-kids-and-maybe-you-should-too). Food and drinks to balance the vata dosha. People with a vata imbalance might benefit from "more protein and fat, along with warming foods," according to Bhatia. Root vegetables, [warm, creamy drinks](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/dairy-free-pink-ayurvedic-rose-quartz-latte-recipe), and a variety of meats can also be nourishing and grounding. [Staying well-hydrated](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/heres-what-to-drink-and-what-not-to-based-on-your-dosha) is also important since this dosha tends to dryness. Pitta Dosha Pitta dosha characteristics. The pitta dosha is linked to fire and is thought to control the endocrine, metabolic, and [digestive systems](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/0-12848/7-foods-that-will-work-wonders-on-your-digestion.html). People who are predominantly pitta can have a medium build, feel cold often, and [have acne-prone skin](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/0-1302/7-Ayurvedic-Skin-Care-Tips-for-Healthy-Glowing-Skin.html). They tend to be busy, high-achieving, and always on the move. An imbalance in pitta can lead to anger, [overexertion and burnout](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/burnout-signs-causes-and-how-to-overcome-it), and skin irritation and rashes. Exercises to balance the pitta dosha. Unsurprisingly, those with a pitta imbalance will benefit from cooling activities. Think taking colder showers and walking next to a body of water (but not while it's super-hot out). The opposite of vata in many ways, pitta-prone people should consider loosening their tight schedules and [saving room for spontaneity](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/how-to-make-the-most-of-your-sunday-according-to-ayurveda). Food and drinks to balance the pitta dosha. Avoid anything hot, spicy, or fermented, and gravitate toward more cooling foods—especially in the summer months. A few pitta-pacifying foods and beverages include [sweet fruits](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/ayurvedic-eating-for-your-dosha-skin-benefits), coconut water, and plenty of grains. Kapha Dosha Kapha dosha characteristics. Kapha is associated with earth and water. It is a stabilizing energy thought to supply water to the body and maintain the [immune system](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/arthritis-and-your-immune-system). Someone who is kapha dominant is calm, grounded, and forgiving. But an imbalance in kapha can lead to jealousy, sluggishness, and weight gain. Exercises to balance the kapha dosha. If kapha is out of whack, some serious [self-care](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/the-best-foot-soak-for-relaxation) is in order. Mental stimulation, [plenty of exercise](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/new-study-finds-you-can-benefit-from-exercise-no-matter-when-you-start), and mindful activities like [meditation and breathwork](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/breathwork-as-medicine-simon-cheng) are essential for those with a kapha imbalance. Food and drinks to balance the kapha dosha. Those who are kapha dominant should avoid oily foods and heavy, dense carbs like pasta and rice. Instead, go for bitter, astringent ingredients and plenty of fresh fruits and veggies. Incorporating ayurvedic wisdom into modern life. In Sanskrit, the word ayurveda translates to "the science of life." Ultimately, ayurvedic medicine is focused on the prevention of disease. Ayurvedic practitioners focus on maintaining the balance of energy through diet, exercise, and [mindfulness](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/0-5979/How-to-Practice-Mindfulness-In-Your-Everyday-Life.html) that they believe is essential to overall health. When [stress levels](https://www.mindbodygreen.com/0-14560/10-reasons-why-stress-is-the-most-dangerous-toxin-in-your-life.html) are low and your body and energy are aligned, the immune system can more effectively ward off disease.
